summary: This article addresses the critical yet overlooked intersection of ethics and diversity in the field of social work. It proposes 'intersectional ethics' as a new ethical framework aimed at enhancing ethical deliberation by utilizing a set of six heuristic questions. These questions are designed to facilitate a deeper understanding of various factors such as positionality, social identity, and moral theories, thereby promoting anti-oppressive ethics and encouraging critical reflection. The article also offers specific recommendations for integrating this framework into social work ethics education.
